title: "you have used ..." in personal settings shows wrong numbers, misleading language
body:
in the top section of the personal settings page, in my 4.5.4 installation there's this bar which shows "you have used 157.1 gb of the available 637.6 gb". however, when viewing the separate folders (either directly on the filesystem, or even when looking at them in the file view), they have over 210 gb of combined size, and 637,6gb isn't any number i can link to the free or total space on my system in any way...  i have a 60g ssd and a 1tb external disk on that system; both the data directory and all local custom mounts refer to the 1tb external hard disk, so it should be more like "of the available 900gb". there is also no quota set for any user, and it's also not the free space on the disk (df -h shows 481gb at the moment).

**expected behavior:** either no or the correct values should be shown - meaning:
1. the sum of all file sizes for this user as first value
2. with the current wording (see below), the second value would have to be the sum of the total disk space where owncloud data can be stored, i.e. on drives which this user has access to - except if there's a lower quota, then the quota should be shown.

one more thing: for another user, i see "you have used 0 b of the available 480.5 gb". the 0b is correct, that user doesn't have any files yet, but the second number is confusing. in this case, it seems to be the free space. i have two remarks regarding that:

1. how can the second number (of the available xxx) differ between users of the same system, unless they use space from somewhere else (e.g. custom mounts)? the only custom mounts used in my scenario are local ones (mapping to the same drive - maybe they are counted twice?) and dropbox - which should only make a 2gb difference (only using the free version).

2. the wording is confusing. if the second number is the free space, then the term "of the available" is misleading. in my opinion, as it is currently worded, the second number should indicate the _total_ space (i.e. all the space that is there for this user to store data, be it used or not), as the "of the" would indicate that the first number is part of what the second shows. if it is supposed to be the _still available_ (i.e. free) space, then the wording is wrong and should be rephrased - the used space is not part of the free space...

my configuration:
apache 2.2.22
mysql 5.5.28
php 5.3.10
all that running on an ubuntu server 12.04 x86_64
